column7: Please tell us, in a few sentences, about the strategy you used to create games. What did you consider? How did you go about it?

column2: 3 pyramidal blocks, 3 bridge blocks, 3 golfballs,3 tall cylindrical blocks, 3 cube blocks, 3 dodgeballs, 3 short cylindrical blocks
column3: build a tower with the figures, make a ramp to see if you can knock down the tower or go through a hole
column4: for each figure knocked down is 1 point
column7: mainly objects and creativity

column2: I would pile all of the bridge blocks,  and the rectangular blocks and prop them in front of the desk, and I would put also the mug on the desk, centered with the blocks underneath.
column3: So, the game would consist in trying to get the golfballs into the mug, by bouncing them on top of the piled rectangular blocks and bridge blocks, while sitting at the other end of the room, eg. on the bed.
column4: Every time you get a golfball into the mug counts as a single point
column7: I thought about something easy to achieve, I don't like moving a lot of stuff around just to pass the time

column2: Grab the 3 golf balls
column3: Using the 3 golf balls start to juggle them and time yourself using the alarm clock.
column4: Each 30 seconds of juggling is worth 10 points, if you manage to lose one ball every 30 seconds is then worth 5 points. If you managed to juggle longer than two minutes with all 3 balls you receive 100 points on top of the points you have already collected but if you only manged to complete two minutes with 2 balls you only receive 50 points on top of your already collected points. The maximum score is 140 points.
column7: I looked at the objects provided and thought what I would do in each situation.

column2: Prepare one of the large triangular ramps and place it in the doggie bed.
column3: Try to stand on the hypotenuse side of the large triangular ramp while balancing it on its right-angled edge.
column4: Have a stopwatch in one hand while balancing and time it. Seconds balanced = score.
column7: I mainly considered what I think I would find fun and challenging when using some of the items available in the room. All my games involved some kind of physics-oriented solution so there is always room to learn and improve ones knowledge of how the items in use interact with one another, as well as the player.

column3: Room Escape
column4: It is a kind of game call escape something that the goal is escape from the place by searching the objects to find clues and keys to escape. Less time you take to escape better the score
column7: I consider a lot the room in question and remind me of games already created in same spot

column2: The two large triangular ramps are placed next to each other in the middle of the room.
column3: The two large triangular ramps are placed next to each other in the middle of the room. The player must slide through them, sit in one of the chairs, spin 4 times, throw all the 3 dodgeballs into the hexagonal bin and then keep the beachball in the air for 20 seconds. The circuit will be timed by the cellphone on the desk.
column4:
Circuit done under 40 seconds: 20 points
Circuit done in 50 seconds:18 points
Circuit done in 60 seconds: 15 points
Circuit done over 60 seconds:13 points
column7: I tried to create simple and easy games that are also fun and help to pass the time.

column2: 3 golfballs, hexagonal bin, 3 triangular blocks, 3 tall cylindrical blocks, curved wooden ramp
column3:
Place curved wooden ramp and then in front of it place hexagonal bin. place 2 tall cylindrical blocks before curved wooden ramp and roll 3 golfballs in order to pass between the 2 tall cylindrical blocks, through the curved wooden ramp and then falling in
the hexagonal bin.
column4: 5 rounds, 3 golfballs each round. Each golfball passing between 2 tall cylindrical blocks and landing inside hexagonal bin gives 5 points. Lose 1 point for each tall cylindrical block the golfball touches and lose 2 points if it doesnt land inside the hexagonal bin.
column7: I triend using common sence and imagine what would I actually do if I was in those specific situations described.

column2: 3 golfballs, curved wooden ramp, hexagonal bin and a mug
column3: You can play a game of throwing three golfballs into something. You can throw the golfballs into 2 recipients, the hexagonal bin and the mug, the balls have to slide on the curved wooden ramp, if not, you don't get any points. Throwing the golfballs into the mug gets you a higher score, but if you throw them into the hexagonal bin you get points too, but less than in the bucket
column4: Scoring into the mug gives you 10 points and into the hexagonal bin only gives you 5.
column7: I just took into account the fun factor, being easy to do and accessibility.

column2: 3 golfballs, mug,3 flat rectangular blocks,2 large triangular ramps, curved wooden ramp,desk lamp
column3: Create a  an obstacle course with the following objects (flat rectangular blocks,2 large triangular ramps, curved wooden ramp,) and  hit the 3 golfballs into the mug with the desk lamp
column4: For a score of 100 you must center the  3golfballs inside the mug 10 times
column7: just looked at the items and imagined whatever simple things could be done

column3: The objective is to guess the right color of one dodgeball and one golfball and get them down from the shelf using large triangular ramp and curved wooden ramp. The player must use the correct blocks to construct a ramp to get the most points. Clues to the puzzle can be found by interacting with the desktop computer, CD, poster, teddy bear, textbook and rug.
column4: 2 points for each correct block. The blocks are: 2 tall cylindrical blocks, 2 bridge blocks, 2 cube blocks, 2 flat rectangular blocks, 2 triangular blocks.
column7: I wanted the player to search the room for objects which will provide the clues to the solution of a simple puzzle or a quest objective. The player must apply the information corretly in order to 'win' the game. These games would probably be most suited for children.

column2: Build a random path with all the blocks with ups and downs, starting with a ramp and ending with a hexagonal bin.
column3: With the path that was build drop a dodgeball at the beginning of the path, preferably starting at a ramp to gain speed and then end inside the hexagonal bin.
column4: Each time the ball makes it inside the bin, one point is scored.
column7: I considered creativity and imagination. A simple game of ball throwing is never boring.

column2: 3 bridge blocks, 2 chairs, hexagonal bin, 3 tall cylindrical blocks
column3: the game is going to be played on the floor. I will place the 3 bridge blocks, 3 tall cylindrical blocks, the hexagonal bin and the 2 chairs one after the other keeping 1 metre of distance between each item.  after creating this "line" each item will represent a level. The palyer has to try to jump over each element and every time the player manage to jump over each item he or she will pass the level.
column4:
you have only one possibility, if you don't manage to jump over an item you will not pass the level and you will start all over again.
every level you pass you will score 1 for each item.
if you manage to jump over multiple items at once you will score 3 times the points.
the quicker you get at the end the higher score you will get
column7: to create my strategy I looked at all the items available and I started imagining what I would do if I had to create a game in that specific room. I visioned myself inside the room

column2: 3 golfballs, mug, hexagonal bin. Take up rug and place hexagonal bin and mug next to each other on the floor halfway between bed and desk
column3: A version of "pong" where you bounce the 3 golfballs  (one at a time) to aim into the mug or hexagonal bin.
column4: 1 point for getting the golfball in the hexagonal bin, three points for getting the golfball in the mug.
column7: I was first trying to make something but then realised that would be one-off so I tried to come up with games that could be played repeatedly and that most people could attempt.
column8: The last one was hard as there were not many items.

column2: The 3 cube blocks, 3 tall cylindrical blocks and the 3 short cylindrical blocks should be moved to the center of the room in an area that the player can see the clock.
column3: In this game, the player can use the clock to keep track of time. Each round, the player has one minute to build a tower using the blocks as tall as they can without it falling over.
column4: Each block that is added to the tower before the time runs out and it falls over is one point gained by the player.
column7: All that I really considered while creating these games were what objects were in the room and what ways I could play with them. I also had to consider how to incorporate a scoring system into each one, because it wasn't something that I would naturally think of to kill time.

column2: 3 dodgeballs, 3 golfballs, hexagonal bin, 2 large triangular ramps, 2 chairs
column3:
Use one of the dodgeballs or the golfballs, the one you prefer the most, place a triangular ramp in front of you, then an hexagonal bin in front of the triangular ramp a few meters away and sit in one of the 2 chairs that will be placed close to triangular ramp.
The objective is to sit on the chair, pick up one of the balls and throw it on the triangular ramp in order to go to the other side and place inside the bin.
column4: You have three attempts, each with different dodgeballs or golfballs but never mixing both types of balls and each attempt you need to place the ball inside the bin in order to receive 10 points maximum for each attempt to a total of 30 points, if the ball doesn't get inside the bin but gets through the triangular ramp then you receive 5 points, if the ball falls while going through the ramp or falls while doing so you receive 0 points.
column7: Throughout my life IÂ´ve always enjoyed to play with any kind of sport ball whether it is a football ball, a baskteball ball, dodgeball, etc... and so I tried to make interesting and objective games not that complex, with the other objects at my disposal such ah a ramp or a bin or a cube and make games where you would need to hit those balls in some objects, or use objects to make the ball go towards other objects and I think that yes are simple games but it can train your accuracy for example and your overall skill with sportsballs.

column2: or 3 dodgeball, 1 large triangular ramp, hexagonal bin.
column3: I throw the ball through the ramp like bowling, and the ball has to get in the bin.
column4: Every time the ball gets in the bin you get 1 point, you have 3 balls in total, but if you don't miss the 3 balls you get the chance to throw another 3 times.
column7: Those games are the ones I've played when i have no internet, I just had to add the score system so it wasn't hard to create them.

column2: To play the game you can make a quick setup with all the items you want to create a circuit into the hexagonal bin, not using one or more balls.
column3: With the setup that you created earlier you will throw the ball into the circuit and you will try to get the ball to pass the obstacles and go through the circuit into the hexagonal bin.
column4: The scoring system will be drawn with the size of the ball and lenght of the circuit created, the golfballs make 30 point when they reach the bin,the dodgeballs make 20 point when they reach the bin and the beachballs make 10 point when they reach the bin, then how bigger the lenght of the circuit is more point are obtained, 10 points per 10 centimeters.
column7: I tried to create simple and straight forward games as possible not to have to do a detailed and complicated explanation of the game.

column2: You have to place some soft things on the ground and make sure that the computer is working properly and can play music.
column3: First, the player has to turn the music on. Then he's dancing with a teddy bear to this song and be careful about pillows, beachball, and golfballs with are on the ground.
column4: Player's starting with 100 points. When a player fell out of rhythm, his score decreases by 1.
column7: I have a really good imagination so it was very easy for me to create these games. It was like instant idea. I don't think the games are perfect but I would play that games by myself personally.
column8: There is no desktop computer in 3rd photo's but it's on the list.

column2: 3 golfballs, a large triangular ramp, the 3 triangular blocks and the 3 bridge block
column3: First, it'd be ideal to clear out the rug. Second, you set up the 3 triangular blocks so that they make a triangular shape from above (as big as you want it to be). That will be your main target. Then, you put the bridge blocks around the shape, a fair distance from it, creating sort of a perimeter; that's another target. Now that you've got your targets, you imagine where you want to throw the golf balls from, and put the large triangular ramp between you and the targets. Now the only thing left to do is to throw them as if they were bowling balls, and using the ramp, make it land in one of the goals.
column4: You only get 3 throws, and a throw that lands in the main target gives you 5 points. A throw that misses the target, but gets caught by the perimeter will give you 2 points. Otherwise, if the ball leaves the perimeter, you'll get no points.
column7: I considered making super-simple games, but thought they might be very boring, so I tried to make something perhaps a-little-more creative. I thought of things I used to do as a child, or even fair games.
column8: There were so many items I could use that at times I became a little overwhelmed.

column2:
bed
hexagonal bin on the bed
curved wooden ramp about 2m to the bed
3 dodgballs
column3: On the bed i'd place the hexagonal bin. About 2m of the bed i'd place the curved wooden ramp. Then, close to the wall of the opposite side of the bed i'd throw 1 dodge ball at a time through the curved wooden ramp trying to place the dodgball in the hexagonal bin
column4: for each dodgeball place inside the bin i'd get 1 point
column7: I tried to use balls and the objective of the game to be to score with them (maybe becase I like a lot of games with balls (football, basketball, volley... even pool). Then I tried to spice it a little with some extra objects so it wouldn't be too simple and boring

column2: In this game all the objects start at the same point design in the picture. All you need is the 3 golfballs, 3 tall cylindrical blocks, 3 cube blocks, 3 short cylindrical blocks, 3 pyramidal blocks, 3 triangular blocks, 3 tall cylindrical blocks, 3 flat rectangular blocks, 3 bridge blocks,  2 large triangular ramps, curved wooden ramp,  3 dodgeballs, beachball.
column3: In this game you will have to make an bowling alley with the object provided. Then you use the balls to play in your bowling alley. This give infinite solutions to the game.
column4: If you use the 3 dodgeballs to strike the blocks you will get lesser points than when you use the 3 golfballs and more than when you use the beachball. Striking the bigger objects give you lesser points than if you strike bigger objects. Striking with the golfballs will multiply by 3 the score you got by striking the objects. If you strike using the dodgeballs it will multiply by 2 and the beachball by 1. Striking the short cylindrical blocks will give 5 points each. Striking the pyramid and bigger cylindrical block will give you 3 points. Striking 3 flat rectangular blocks and using the 3 bridge blocks will give you 1 points each. The final scores is calculated by the strike points and the multiplying that to the score of each ball.
column7: Game I already know, like escape rooms and sports games like bowling games.

column2: The set up would be putting the hexagonal bin in the middle of the room then line up the 2 large triangular ramps 2 feet apart and 1 foot in front of the hexagonal bin. Then use the beachball, 3 dodgeballs and 3 golfballs as throwing objects.
column3: The point of this game is to get the throwing objects (beachball, 3 dodgeballs and 3 golfballs) into the hexagonal bin by bouncing the throwing objects off of the 2 large triangular ramps placed in front of the hexagonal bin and then getting it into the hexagonal bin.
column4: The score will work depending on what throwing objects you are using. The beach ball is 10 points for getting it into the hexagonal bin, the 3 dogeballs are 15 points for getting it in and the golf balls are 20 points for getting it in. If you miss a bounce off one of the triangular ramps that will be minus 5 points.
column7: I considered what I had in the room then I tried to see what game would work best with what I had.
column9: I enjoyed this study very much, please do more.

column3: The player will use all of the different blocks available to create a course for the golf balls that starts from the bottom self that is located in front of the bed and leads to the hexagonal bin (the inside of which, is the finish-line). The player has 3 attempts (using the 3 gold balls) to perfect his course. For each attempt the player will also be using the cellphone to time how long it takes for the golf ball to make it inside the hexagonal bin or untill the golf ball falls down to the floor.
column4: The score is calculated by adding the seconds timed in all 3 attempts and multiplying the total number of seconds by 10.
column7: I tried to immerse myself in the situation by imagining myself being bored inside the rooms that were shown. Then, by examining the available items, I tried to come up with some fun and a little challenging games that would help me pass my time.
column9: Very creative experiement. I very much enjoyed my time with it.

column2:
Needed: two teddy bears placed on the bed with about 30cm away from each other,
3 dodgeballs and the beach ball placed on the floor near the desk chair. and the desk chair need to be put away, maybe in the place where the beach ball originally located. Also the hexagonal bin need to be placed between the teddy bears (on the bed).
column3: So the game would be, crossing/kicking the balls (dodgeballs and the beach ball) towards the three targets located on the bed (teddy bears and the hexagonal bin), need to hit the teddy bears using the balls, and also to kick the ball into the hexagonal bin.
column4: the scoring system would be the following: hitting the teddy bear= 50 points, putting one of the three balls into the hexagonal bin = 100 points. Need to reach 1000 Points to finish the game.
column6: I would surely reach the 1000 points, because I am good at playing with the ball.
column7: I tried to make it fun for me, I tried to play something that I would enjoy. Basically I only play games that I would enjoy and feel it is fun and challenging, so I tried to benefit from what the room has and create a fun game for myself.
column9: Actually, as I used the balls in the first and second games, it was hard to create a game in the 3rd room because all what I saw at first is playing with the balls differently, but then I tried to think of something instead of the balls, and still I could enjoy.

column2:
I would leave the blocks as they are on the shelves
I would also take the hexagonal bin and place it underneath the shelves
I would put the three golf balls in my pocket
I would also set up a chair at the other end of the room (near the desk area)
I would place the remaining tall cylindrical blocks and the bridge blocks on top of the right shelf (above the bed)
column3:
I would throw the golf balls at the blocks (short cylindrical blocks, tall cylindrical blocks, pyramidal blocks, triangular blocks etc. which are placed on the shelves near the bed)

The aim of the game would be to throw off the blocks from the shelves and into the hexagonal bin using the golf balls
column4:
Blocks that are lying on the bottom shelves - 1 point
Blocks that are lying on the top shelves - 2 points
Blocks that are lying on top of the shelves themselves - 3 points
column7:
I considered the objects which could actually help me create a game which actually makes sense.
I also considered my preferences when it comes to playing with toys in a room, completely on your own and bored to bits.
column8:
I slowly ran out of ideas on what game to create
I honestly believe that the more random objects you come across within a certain room the harder it becomes to create a fun game

column2: 3 golfballs, 3 dodgeballs, one beachball and the hexagonal bin will be used. The bin will be placed in the middle of the room and I would be sitting on the bed, facing the bin. I would have all balls next to me on the bed.
column3: One could play a game where the balls would have to be thrown right into the hexagonal bin, which is in the middle of the room, from the bed. It would start with the easier, golf balls, then the 3 dodgeballs and lastly, the beachball.
column4: Each scored ball (a ball thrown correctly into the bin) would represent points. Each golfball represents one point, each dodge ball represents 2 points and the beach ball, as it is the biggest and most difficult to throw exactly in the bin, would represent 3 points. The maximum of points possible to obtain would be 12.
column7: I looked around the room and wanted to create a game that is not extremely complicated, but it's also a bit more than playing with a teddy bear and a ball. I wanted to create some sort of competition with myself and a couple of them include building structures or a time limit. I wanted to use at least 7-8 objects so the game has the potential to be fun, but I didn't want to use almost all the objects in the room so they would not be linked to each other. I wanted to give myself a few 'turns' to try get better at the game but the game is also not too time consuming, so I can end it whenever I get tired or bored.

column2: hexagonal bin, 3 dodgeballs, 3 golfballs. the player is opposite the hexagonal bin, all other things are within his reach
column3: player is situated opposite to the hexagonal bin, the balls are within his reach. he must throw 3 golfballs to use dodgeball. any golfball is scored for 10 points while every miss of golfball throw is -10 points. when he throws 3 golfballs without mistake he can throw dodgeball. one dodgeball throw is scored 30 points. while one dodgeball miss is -30. to win he must have 60 points
column4: sucessful golfball throw is named gol, unsucesfull is fol. sucessful dodgeball throw is dol while miss lol
column7: i consider easyness as you ask for a game to pass a time. i consider throwing objects the main formula for a games.
column8: is hard to visualize the room while having only pictures, maybe 3d look like in google maps would be easier for me to navigate

column2: 3 golfballs, CD, poster, rug
column3: This game is really simple, place your rug away from you, put your poster on it, and then put your CD in the middle of your poster. Your goal is to roll a ball into that cd. You have 3 balls, and 3 areas that give you points. You can roll 1 ball only once, however when your first ball is on the rug, you can move it by hitting it with the next ball, so it moves into the poster. The game ends when you already used your 3 balls.
column4: If the ball is on the tug, you gain 1 point, if the ball is on the poster, you gain 2 points, and if your ball is on CD you gain 3 points. You gain 0 points for the ball that is on the floor instead of this 3 areas.
column7: I didnt wanted to choose specified object at first, so i made 2 out of 3 games that you can play using any objects that are in the room so i can build my own strategy while preparing to my game. However on the 3rd game i decided to create something simular to the curling game, because its really simple and satisfying game.
column8: No, but i wanted to think more about special mechanics in the games, so i can make them more intresting.

column2: 2 large triangular ramps, 3 tall cylindrical blocks, 3 cube blocks
column3: the game consisted of making a bridge with 2 large triangular ramps, 3 tall cylindrical blocks, 3 cube blocks, and how did we make the bridge? using the 2 large triangular at the entrance and exit of the bridge, the 3 tall cylindrical blocks lying down and finally using the 3 cube blocks as pillars to support the bridge.
column4: to make the score we had to stand on the bridge and the number of seconds we could take was the score we had
column7: my strategy to create the games was due to the creativity I have and the childhood I had and gave me a lot of knowledge of games when I am alone
column8: it was quite long, and very specific

column3: Sort the geometrical shapes (pyramidal blocks, bridge blocks, golfballs, tall cylindrical blocks, triangle ramps, cube blocks, tall cylindrical blocks, short cylindrical blocks, flat rectangular blocks, dodgeballs) by shape and colour, from smallest to largest and by colour in a particular order decided beforehand; the order can differ from game to game, but it must be decided before starting the game.
column4: For each item correctly placed before the time runs out the player gets 1 point. The maximum allowed time is 2 minutes and the aim is to sort as many items as possible in that time and when the participant sorts all of the items in less than 2 minutes, he can try to beat his score by decreasing the allowed time.
column7: I tried to create a fun activity and one that was challenging the player and make him not give up.
